action.action-desc: Ms. Houlahan (for herself, Ms. Salazar, and Mrs. Bice of Oklahoma) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committee on Education and Labor, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To protect and expand access to donor milk, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Access to Donor Milk Act of 2022.

paragraph.text: The term donor milk means human milk that is processed without additives by a nonprofit milk bank.
The term nonprofit milk bank means a milk bank that—

subparagraph.text: is accredited by an accrediting body that is recognized by, or meets standards established by, the Food and Drug Administration for purposes of accrediting milk banks;
collects, tests, processes, pasteurizes, and distributes donor milk; and
is described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (26 U.S.C. 501(c)(3)) and exempt from tax under section 501(a) of such Code (26 U.S.C. 501(a)).

paragraph.text: Human milk is the optimal first food for infants.
Medically vulnerable infants, including those born prematurely and those with congenital or acquired conditions, derive significant health benefits from human milk.
Mothers of medically vulnerable infants often face unique obstacles to producing enough milk. When a parent’s milk is not available, the provision of donor milk improves health outcomes.
Nonprofit milk banks provide an essential medical service.
The nonprofit milk banking model of donor non-remuneration and standardized processing of single ingredient pools ensures a safe and high-quality product for the Nation’s most vulnerable infants.

section.text: Section 17 of the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 (42 U.S.C. 1786) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (b)(4), by inserting (including support for donor milk activities) after promotion; and
in subsection (h)(1)(C), by adding at the end the following:

clause.text: A State agency may use amounts made available under clause (i) for the collection and storage of unprocessed donations of human milk, the transfer of such milk to a nonprofit milk bank, and to make donor milk available to program participants.

section.header: Emergency capacity funding for milk banks

subsection.text: The Secretary shall award competitive grants to eligible entities for expanding emergency capacity with respect to banking donor milk.
An eligible entity seeking a grant under this section shall submit an application to the Secretary at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Secretary may require.
Expanding emergency capacity pursuant to a grant under this section may include—

paragraph.text: publicizing the need for donor milk;
providing resources to patients, making patients aware of donor milk, and providing information to clinicians about donor milk;
covering donor milk processing fees;
increasing staffing and supplies needed at nonprofit milk banks; and
purchasing consumable products needed for donor milk processing.
The term eligible entity means an entity that—

subparagraph.text: is recognized by the Food and Drug Administration as an accrediting body for nonprofit milk banks; and
in the application submitted under subsection (b), demonstrates, with respect to such entity—

clause.text: a rapid increase in demand for donor milk; or
a shortage of supplies needed to operate a nonprofit milk bank.

paragraph.text: The term Secretary means the Secretary of Health and Humans Services, acting through the Commissioner of Food and Drugs.

subsection.text: For the purposes of carrying out this section, there are authorized to be appropriated $3,000,000 for fiscal year 2023, and such sums as may be necessary for each fiscal year thereafter.

section.text: The Child Nutrition Act of 1966 (42 U.S.C. 1771 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subsection.text: The Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, shall establish a donor milk awareness program to—

paragraph.text: educate the public on donor milk and nonprofit milk banks; and
publicize the need for donor milk at nonprofit milk banks.

subsection.text: In carrying out the program described in subsection (a), the Secretary may—

paragraph.text: develop or assist others to develop appropriate educational materials, including public service announcements, promotional publications, and press kits for the program described in subsection (a);
publish information about the program described in subsection (a) on the Department’s website; and
distribute or assist other to distribute such materials appropriate for public and private individuals and entities.

subsection.text: The Secretary is authorized to enter into cooperative agreements with Federal agencies, State and local governments, and other entities to carry out the program described in subsection (a).
In this section, the term donor milk has the meaning given the term in section 2 of the Access to Donor Milk Act of 2022.
For purposes of carrying out this section, there are authorized to be appropriated $1,000,000 for fiscal year 2023, and such sums as may be necessary for each fiscal year thereafter.

section.header: CDC public awareness campaign with respect to donor milk from nonprofit milk banks

subsection.text: The Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, shall expand and intensify the activities of the Centers to include a public awareness campaign with respect to donor milk from nonprofit milk banks.
The public awareness campaign under subsection (a) shall include the distribution of educational materials to—

paragraph.text: clinicians, such as pediatric specialists, pediatricians, obstetricians, pediatric nutritionists, midwives, and lactation specialists; and
expecting and new parents.

section.header: Clarifying the regulatory status of donor milk

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, shall issue a rule to clarify the regulatory status (and any associated categorization) of donor milk provided by a nonprofit milk bank.

Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, shall submit to Congress a report specifying the regulatory categorization of donor milk provided by a nonprofit milk bank under the rule issued under subsection (a).
